												Tower Wars is a tower defense game combined with army building. This indie title was released in August 2012, so has been around for a while coming in with about 400k owners on Steam. As with other tower defense games, you start out with a blank battlefield, although this version of tower defense is slightly different to others, you are also fighting against an opponent, who is also building towers on their blank battlefield. The aim of the game is to get your army into the enemies base to destroy their castle before they destroy yours.  Tower Wars has two currency systems, Gold and Battle points - you are able to generate gold via the mines which are already located on your map; you can do the usual technique with tower defense games and upgrade them so that they generate more gold and are quicker at it. Battle points come through sending units to your opponent and working their way to the castle, this of course requires gold though. You build units from your barracks with gold, there is a build queue which you can fill up however you please with different assorted units which you can train, and then push them all out in one go. Your barracks has a cool down so you can only push one wave out every 40 seconds or so. Some units are basic, some have their own special abilities, and some even increase the stats of the whole wave, regardless of whether they are near the units or not. The tower building side of things is again, very similar to other tower defense games, you are able to position your towers pretty much anywhere you want on the map, allowing you to create all sorts of death traps, and corridors that your foe has to battle through, obviously the more ground the opponent has to cover, the more damage you can do to them with your turrets. There are plenty of the normal sort of turrets, such as cannons and arrow launchers, but there are also some really unique ones, such as a huge fan that pushes your opponents back in a certain direction, this makes for some great end of hallway traps!  All of the turrets are able to be upgraded in the usual fashion too, however I didn't really find the need to do that in the single player mode.Tower Wars has a really nice looking graphic and art style; they are really polished and it looks like a lot of care and attention has gone into making this a beautiful steam-punk looking game.  The difficulty in Tower Wars takes a huge ramp up once you get past the tutorial. I will say though, the game's tutorial is really helpful and gets you to grips with the UI and all of the basic elements of the game. It does leave out a few bits that mean you have to go digging around and use a bit of trial and error to see what is what, but that's part of the fun of this type of game.  There are also an abundance of guides, and wiki posts out there if you really want to get into the nitty gritty of it. Since the game is almost four years old now, the multiplayer scene seems to have died down a bit, at the time of writing this there are only  ~30 people playing the game, but thankfully the game does have the option for co-op, so that may peek the attention of some peopleTechnically, this game has a lot of graphical options, allowing you to cater it for your rigs power and capability, coming with plenty of resolution options too. I have put about six hours into Tower Wars so far, and given that matches against the UI/Bots can sometimes last anywhere between 45 minutes and an hour, you can expect to get a lot of gameplay out of this even on the single player mode. If you manage to find yourself a group of friends to play this with, you are looking at a major time sink with ample amounts of fun and content.  I will definitely be carrying on playing Tower Wars after writing this review, since it also has that addicted sort of gameplay that I just cannot put down. Thankfully, due to the price of Tower Wars being £5,59, I am going to strongly recommend this title, if it was any more I would have just said to pick it up when on sale due to the lack of multiplayer activity, but because it is already a low price as it stands, I can easily say you will get at least five or six hours of enjoyment out of it. Hardcore tower defense fans should not miss out on this game!1) Stay away2) Only recommended when on sale3) Recommended4) Highly recommended5) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

												Tower Wars is an interesting idea bogged down by its excessive attempts to condense and entire tower defense experience into a single match.The basic concept of Tower Wars is a competitive TD game where you control both the towers and the enemies, and have to balance throwing tons of grunts at the enemy castle while building up your own defenses to keep theirs away. Adding onto this is a huge upgrade tree, from unlocking new grunt types, to passive upgrades for all units, to upgrading your towers and already unlocked grunts. Essentially everything can be upgraded several times over, and with a limited amount of resources you need to pay careful attention to what you invest in or else be overrun by the other player.If this sounds like a lot to take in, that's because it is. Tower Wars is absurdly involved, as it takes the features that would normally be slowly added over the course of a typical TD game and instead gives you them all for the one self contained match you are already in. As a result it's incredibly overwhelming, and causes matches to stretch on for far longer than they have any right to. The tutorial match alone took nearly an hour, and my first match against the easiest AI opponent in the game about 30 minutes more (which ultimately ended in my defeat). If you're going up against a real human opponent of equal skill, expect this time per match to only rise further, which creates a huge commitment on the player that could ultimately prove for naught.Ultimately Tower Wars asks too much of the player without giving them a reason to stick with it through the long periods of tedium that inevitably occur after the first 10-15 minutes when you've placed most of your towers and begin the long game of tug of war, as you incrementally chip away at each other's castles until someone gets a lucky break and finally pushes through. The concept is a really neat one, but the way it's executed here is dull and overly complex to the point I was begging for defeat simply so the match would be over. I love TD games, probably more than I should, but nothing about Tower Wars ever manifested itself into anything fun or engrossing and just left me feeling like I'd wasted my time and had nothing to show for it.

												Tower Wars is the tower defense genre taken to its logical conclusion, a game where you both defend with towers and attack other peoples' towers. To that end it's mainly a multiplayer game, though the last major update added ten levels of bots to lose to without anyone knowing your shame. It's a good thing too, because the odds of you getting a match against a person aren't very good these days.Each match gives you command over a castle, a barracks, and large tracts of hex-gridded land, all mirrored by your opponent. Your task is to send waves of attackers to destroy your foe's castle while maintaining a field of towers to defend your own castle. The resource that fuels both of these labors is gold, mined from upgradable plots in your territory, so right away you have a balance that must be struck between offense and defense. In addition, your attackers earn Battle Points for the time they spend (alive) in enemy territory. These points are used to unlock new units, upgrade your units, and upgrade your mines.If all this is starting to sound complicated, well, it is. You need to be sending troops to attack, upgrading those troops, upgrading your mines, and managing your own towers, all based out of two resource pools. And yes, just the tower defense part is full-fledged tower defense, with the ability to place upwards of a hundred towers on a single map, of eight different types and three upgrade levels. Layering further complexity over that, while an interesting idea, makes the game a huge struggle to keep up with. It's basically Build Orders: The Game, so if that was your favorite part of Starcraft, there might be something here for you to latch onto.Even so, it's hard to give a positive review to a multiplayer-focused game with no player base. None of my half-dozen attempts to find a match, ranked or unranked over several days, met with success. Poking around the forums it seems there are only a few dozen active players left, and there may be something wrong with matchmaking that the developers have not addressed. It's just as well, because the complexity pushes it up into DOTA territory, long matches and all. A single round can last thirty minutes to an hour, and a loss after all that time really hurts because it earns you nothing. There are no unlocks or points or anything to chase, just match after match. And when you can't even find one, that's a problem.

												In short: This is an AWESOME multiplayer tower defense game, but not too many people play it, so you should convince your friends to get it. You need a few hours to master all the mechanics, but then it's great entertainment.You and your opponent both have castles and barracks, and you need to send waves to destroy each other, while simultaneously upgrading your units and castles as well as tending to your gold mines. Gold is mainly needed for recruiting units, and as long as they are within enemy territory, they earn "battle points" for you, which you need for upgrades. This makes for some challenging gameplay, as you need gold to earn battle points, but also battle points to get upgrades to earn more gold, ...There are many different units, each with unique attributes - speed, health, damage dealt (against opponent's castle), armor, shield. Some have special abilities, e.g. they increase other units' speed or improve their shields.Similarly, there are lots of different towers with unique strengths and weaknesses, e.g. arrow towers, cannons, lava distributors, fans (to slow down the enemy's units) etc.There are a few maps shipped with the game and you can download additional maps from the community. The gold mines are always placed randomly, which means that for every match, you need to come up with a new path around which to build your defense towers (although you will always be using the same basic structures).I recommend that you buy this on sale and get additional keys for your friends, because as mentioned above, it's hard to even find opponents for multiplayer, and the matching can take ages. But I have spent way too many hours playing against buddies now and we're all hooked!PROS:[+] Challenging game mechanics[+] Awesome multiplayer mode (1v1, 2v2, 3v3)[+] Many maps to choose from and random adjustments in each round[+] Very cool steampunk settingCONS:[-] Steep learning curve (although this becomes rewarding if you don't give up early)[-] Very few people "out there" for multiplayer matches (but it's more fun with friends anyway)[-] Boring co-op mode

												In a World where Tower Defense games flood the Market, where one is like any other with just miniscule changes there is sometimes someone trying to switch things up a little.technically, the principle of Tower Wars has been used in tons of WarCraft 3 Maps before. but still, this is a TD game that still manages to stand out.Because your enemy is not a set of 20 pre-made waves.It is a Human.Yes, Tower Wars, as Avertised is a PvP tower Defense Game. And while it follows the "Mazing" style of TDs (you have no predetermined path enemies take. you have a patch of land and the enemies will take the shortest route towards your Fortress) it also forces you to focus on how you will attack. You gain resources by killing enemies and having your people waddle as far as they can.Now the Towers and Enemies are where the fun starts. You are not presented with the standart "Normal tower/ Faster but weaker tower/Splash Tower/Slow Tower" variety, but rather towers that focus on different kinds of Health as well as some supporting towers, like a wind turbine that slows enemies in its path or a huge pot that throws boiling oil to all its sides.As far as the offensive units go, you go from the why do I worry-kind of standart waddler, faster waddlers, healing waddlers, shielding waddlers, carrying waddlers, as well as Upgrades for them. in the end I believe you stand with as many supporting units as you have actual damaging units.Rounds may be short (if any of the players really messes up his BO) or can draw out to a 2 hour "We all send a full wave of our biggest units, all fully upgraded through each others maze and look what happens"-Stalemate. but even those are fun, because its like a snail race. In the end you only win or lose by a hairs width.Also, Bots in 10 difficulty flavors have been implemented. So if you cant find a match (or just wanna get back in form) you can always challenge one of those to get your TD Madness on

												I recently got the game(2$ on discount) and played around 15times. I like it! It is a pretty good Maze building TD and it definetely worthed the 2$.There are practically two types of games: Tower Defense and Tower Wars ( for those familiar with old Warcraft3 maps)If you like competitive tower defense games, I'd say give it a shot!Some game features:Tower Defense type is played vs AI; Tower Wars types can be played both vs other players or vs AI.It can be played in max 3v3 players, or 3 Co-op vs AI.There are around 5-6 maps that you can play on, and every new round the layout is a little changed so you have to adapt your maze from game to game.The game is based on two resources: gold and battle points. Gold is earned every few seconds based on your income(which increases by buying/upgrading miners). Gold is used for building/upgrading towers and also for sending units.Battle points are earned by the units you send out. Battle points are spent for unit upgrades, unlocking new units, buying minersThere aren't as many types of towers or creep units types as I'd wish but it ok:- around 8 types of towers ( each can be upgraded 3 times - but it's a liniar upgrade, no branches or other abilities/customization of towers)- around 10 units(again each with some upgrades)- castle upgrades for armor or damage- a pretty complex tree structure for speed/armor/shield/health and other stuff as general upgrades for all unitsAt first it was a little strange the way you choose/upgrade towers(hold and drag mouse) but I got used with it and then I found out you can also use key shortcuts(shift+click,ctrl+click)

												Tower Wars,It's not your average tower defence game. Sure it has a survival mode to play it that way but that's not the sole action of this game. It's a tower defender and attacker! That's right you have to go on the offence or no matter how great you planning if you only defend you will fail. In fact if your balance of attach vs defence is even a little off you will fail. The computer baddys are tough, and may even break you heh. The real grabber with this game though is the online portion. You can battle with or against friends and strangers from across the world. Yes I used the plural, you can join with up to two other people per team (3 total) for a 6 player game! This is a fantasticly fun way to play. Mixing more than one mind into the game makes it a lot of fun, and a bit more challenging. Things happen fast, so don't plan on a extended set up period. A game can be completed in just a few turns or it can last for up to an hour (In one battle I had so far) all depending on the skill level and a little bit of luck in mine placements which are always random. The good:Instant funDecent "Cartoony" graphicssmooth, lag free playPlay with friends! New exciting twist to the tower defence genreThe bad:Can be a little slow to loadYou don't get the option to "Rematch" and the game quits out on it's own after a match. So no chance to ask the other player to a hosted battle for a rematch either.The above makes meeting new people that play and growing your circle in the game a bit harder than it should be.You can always use the steam "Recently Played" list but you shouldn't have to.

												Tower Wars pits you against an AI as you are trying to conquer each other's HQ, on a hex battlefield, where you have to build defense towers to stop the enemy units, while improve the mines to get more resources to fund your factories, upgrade your units, and eventually produce enough units to conquer the enemy HQ. The game uses a whimsical / comical / steampunk look for its units, which hides a serious RTS underneath. There is a serious tower defense game (where you have to build towers to "manage" the enemy horde by making them walk through your field of fire. And yes, you can improve the towers too. It's a regular tower defense game. There is resource management in that you have to control the mines to ensure you have proper flow of resources to fuel your tower building as well as unit making and unit improvement research. You mainly do this by making sure the mines are controlled by towers, and improved to ensure they have good throughput. Then you need to research units, each of which have a different use against certain types of enemy towers. Some are fast but low armor, some are juggernauts that move slowly, some heal, some shield, etc. And add them, in the right order, to yoru build queue, and hopefully, push the enemy back enough to take out his HQ. There are many different maps and different AI to keep you busy. If you can take the art style, this game can be interesting.

												FlynnLivesSep 1, 201210FINALLY! Someone made an actual Tower Wars game! The mods were so much fun, so it's awesome that SuperVillain made an actual game to pretty much officially kick off the genre (I think?)! But it also lets you customize all settings for weaker machines too, and even looks pretty good at lower settings. Looks like a miniatures set up! Posted: June 28, 2013
												Tower wars is a steampunk, competitive, Tower Defense game that challenges the preconceptions of the genre by putting you in control of not only your towers, but the lemmings that throw themselves at the defenses of your opponent.It requires maintaining a delicate balance between building your towers and upgrading (and purchasing) your troops.  Focus too much on your towers, and your enemy will overwhelm you with a superior economy; but focus too much on creating an army and your defenses will fall to even the puniest wave.The ecnomy of the game requires two currencies:  Gold (used to purchase troops, unlock new troops, and build and upgrade towers) which is mined through randomly placed mines that must be upgraded, and Battle Points (used to upgrade toops and mines) which is gained through sending troops into battle.  The interdependency of these two currencies further requires maintaining a delicate balance between offense and defense.Battles can be decisive and quick if the skills are mismatched; but if you find a good opponent, then you'll find yourself in for a campaign of attrition which could take upwards of two hours.  It's a high stakes tower defense game that offers a high amount of replayability; but the lack of map content (three total) leaves a lot to be desired when it comes to diversity of content.

												Tower Wars twists the tower defense genre by taking into the world of online competitive multiplayer gaming. Each player is tasked with using a variety of unique structures to force enemy units into mazes of death while at the same time creating their own army to assault the enemy’s home fortress. The game is a nice, fresh twist on an established formula but Tower Wars’ most glaring fault is the absence of a single player mode. Without it, new players are forced into a online matches against experienced players which is more than enough to discourage repeat play.Tower Wars feels as if it were designed specifically for hardcore strategists. With a tutorial that skips important concepts and the tendency for matches to become one sided. Still, after you get the hang of it and learn the strategies, this game turns into an enjoyable experience.

Each player is tasked with using a variety of unique structures to force enemy units into mazes of death while at the same time creating their own army to assault the enemy’s home fortress. The game is a nice, fresh twist on an established formula but Tower Wars’ most glaring fault is the absence of a single player mode. Without it, new players are forced into a online matches against experienced players which is more than enough to discourage repeat play.Tower Wars feels as if it were designed specifically for hardcore strategists. With a tutorial that skips important concepts and the tendency for matches to become one sided. Still, after you get the hang of it and learn the strategies, this game turns into an enjoyable experience.

Posted: July 7, 2014
												I love Tower Defense games so much, and this game is REALLY FUN if you enjoy TD games. One of the greatest features of this game is you have to actively send out "creeps" against your opponent while still maintaining your own tower defense line. You also have to manage your income in the form of mines (you can upgrade them task more miners)The upgrading is very basic, max level 3 for towers; however, there is a good amount of diversity for the macro-upgrading trees. For this, you have to spend both money AND battle points. You get battle points by sending troops out (most likely to die), so playing defensively might not be the best option if your oppnent is beating you in gold and battlepoint revenue.You can use your towers to make mazes for the creep to pass through, and the feedback showing exactly where the creeps will travel is really helpful. Admittedly, I've taken lessons from the AI's layout. The learning curve is pretty good despite the extra mechanics, I think the only thing people need to be aware of is how critical getting battlepoints is - balancing your income is key. There is no point of having 10000+ gold if you're waiting on your battlepoints to upgrade your stuff.Aesthetically, the game is very nice and charming. I'm used to towers getting the most insignificant aesthetic changes in old school TD games, but all of the towers here come with their own newer, badder look. The feedback for enemy health, movement, etc is very seamless - so you can still keep track of how much damage you're doing despite 100 catapults shrouding an enemy (pretty good tactic in all TDs actually - artillery for the win!)For the price, I would definitely recommend getting it, especially if you're a fan of tower defense games!

												I really didn't pay any attention to this game when I picked it up in a bundle last year. Idled for cards, made some money. My son actually played it, then challenged me to a match. I've got to say its a pretty fun game. The jist of it is that you play tower defense against your opponent while also sending waves of units against them. There is gold from mining and battlepoints from sending units (more BP the longer they last on the map). You need both. Towers and units are bought with gold, upgrades are bought with BP, and units are unlocked with both.What I find interesting is that you need to balance sending out lots of units to get upgrades, and you need to keep your maze strong to stop enemy units from getting BP for upgrades.The main downside to this game is that there are some fairly predictable setups that will win matches against players that expect a regular TD game. If you find an opponent that uses a similar setup, the game can progress, but otherwise its usually quite one sided.Overall, I think its a fun game, with some features that make it different from the rest of the TD out there.

Entweder sind sie von den Farben her zu knallig, inhaltlich zu abgedreht, zu langatmig, zu schwer, zu schnell usw. usw. Für einen echten Nörgler kann die Liste nicht lang genug sein. Erfreulicherweise konnte ich mich bisher vor allen selbstgemachten Negativerfahrungen bewahren, da ich bis zum Test von „Tower Wars“ eine wahre Tower-Defense Jungfrau war. Daher kann ich vorab sagen, dass mich das Game mehr als positiv überrascht hat. Aber kommen wir doch erst einmal dazu, was die Damen und Herren von SuperVillain Studios so geschaffen haben.TOWER WARS REVIEW – WAS IST DAS EIGENTLICH?Nach kurzer Spielzeit wurde für mich eines sofort deutlich. Tower Wars ist ein ordentliches Tower-Defense Game, mit ordentlich Zack! Aber kommen wir doch erst mal zum Inhalt. Obwohl ich an dieser Stelle langatmig die Mechanik eines Tower-Defense Spiel erklären könnte…. ach was solls. Wie man vielleicht aus dem englischen Ableiten kann, beinhalten Tower-Defense Games Türme und Abwehr. Kombiniert man das ganze kommt man schnell auf den Trichter, dass die Türme als Mittel zum Zweck verwendet werden. Und zwar um seine eigene Basis vor den anrückenden Gegenerhorden zu verteidigen um parallel dazu, mit seinen eigenen Truppen, dass gegnerische Lager bis auf die Grundmauern niederzubrennen. Klingt das nicht schön? Nicht nur ähnlich, sondern exakt so, geht es auch in Tower Wars zu. Kommen wir daher also mal zum eigentlichen Spiel.TOWER WARS – GAMEPLAYIm Großen und Ganzen ist Tower Wars sehr simpel aufgebaut. Man hat neben dem Tutorial (welches verhältnismäßig lang, humorvoll ist und auf angenehme Weise die Spielmechanik erklärt) weitere Spielmodi wie z.B. den Multiplayer und der Kampf gegen die künstliche Intelligenz. Bevor man ein Spiel gegen Mensch oder KI startet, empfiehlt es sich das Tutorial zu spielen. Hier werden alle wichtigen Spielmechaniken erklärt und dies auf eine sehr humorvolle Art und Weise. Wir lassen jetzt mal unsere Fantasie spielen und stellen uns vor, wir sind im Game. Was jetzt? Im Endeffekt ist das Spielprinzip sehr einfach. Man selber (als auch der der Feind) hat eine eigene Basis, die durch das Setzen von Türmen, vor den heranrückenden Feinden beschützt werden soll. Dazu hat man eine Auswahl an unterschiedlichen Türmen. Egal ob es sich dabei um überdimensionale Armbrüste handelt, Teslaspulenartige Türme die an die Zeiten von Command & Conquer erinnern, oder riesenhafte Katapulte für Distanzangriffe. Tower Wars bietet alles! Türme haben in Tower Wars allerdings noch eine weitere Funktion. Neben der Verteidigung dienen sie auch als Möglichkeit, um die KI vor ihrer vorgegebenen Marschroute abzulenken. So laufen die Gegner immer auf einer exakt vorgegebenen Route lang, die im Spiel entweder blau oder rot markiert ist. Durch das setzen der Türme, kann diese Route entsprechend verlängert werden, was auch nötig ist. Der Feind baut im Laufe des Spiel größere und stärkere Einheiten, was ein Risiko für den Durchbruch der eigenen Verteidigungslinie immens erhöht. Neben dem Bau von Türmen ist es allerdings auch möglich eigene Einheiten zu bauen. Dies wird ermöglicht durch Gold und Battlepoints. Gold lässt sich einfach in den umliegenden Minen absammeln, während Battlepoints durch blutige Schlachten gewonnen werden können. Neben dem Einheitenbau lassen sich mit Battlepoints und Gold auch Upgrades erkaufen um die feindliche Basis noch schneller zu stürmen. TOWER WARS – GRAFIK UND SOUNDWas lässt sich schon sagen. Ich persönlich finde die Grafik sehr gelungen. SuperVillain Studios ist ein Indie Studio welches nicht über ein Budget von mehreren Millionen Dollar verfügt, daher ist das was dem Konsumenten präsentiert wird mehr als ausreichend. Es gibt keine groben Ecken und Kanten und mir sind bisher keine groben Grafikpatzer aufgefallen. Der Sound ist allerdings erste Sahne! Neben den klangvollen Geräuschen ist insbesondere die Vertonung der Stimmen PERFEKT gelungen. Selten habe ich einen so hervorragenden, englischen Akzent in einem Videospiel erleben dürfen. Einfach nur herrlich. FAZITMachen wir es kurz und schmerzlos. Tower Wars ist ein überaus gelungener Indie Titel von SuperVillain Studios, der sich nicht hinter anderen Tower-Defense Spielen zu verstecken brauch. Das Gameplay ist schnell, manchmal vielleicht etwas zu schnell. Mit etwas Übung und stimmiger Aufteilung seiner Türme ist die erste Defense Line geschaffen, wodurch erst mal brav Battlepoints gesammelt werden können. Tower Wars ist auf Steam erhältlich und dies sogar in mehreren Versionen. Während eine Kopie des Spiels schlappe 7,99 Euro kostet, ist das Tower Wars Team Pack, bestehend aus drei Kopien, für 19,90 Euro zu haben. Für Tower-Defense Fans sollte das Spiel durch die unterschiedlichen Spielmodi  lange Spaß machen. Ansonsten eignet es sich durch den Preis von 7,99 Euro auch wunderbar zu giften.Zusammenfassend lässt sich sagen, dass Tower Wars ein spaßiges Spiel für Einsteiger ist, welches besonders durch seinen Humor und Preis beeindruckt. Daher verteile ich für Tower Wars ganze vier von fünf Sternen.

												Tower Wars is a title that launched pretty successfully, and got the thumbs up from players and critics. Unfortunately, due to awful handling of multiplayer rankings and accounts, unwarranted bans and poor tutorial elements, this one started rolling down the ratings hill shortly after release, and has come to rest somewhere near the bottom.Most of the problems of this game stem from handling of multiplayer, and while there are strong reasons not to buy it, there is also a fantastic hex-based strategic tower defence game here for the right players.HighlightsTower Wars has a great art style and hero gimmicks, and the hex based placement atop towering maps works really well visually. The gameplay is also new and unique enough for the genre that it does stand out a little. Most importantly, the gameplay is genuinely fun and has some strategic elements, resource management, and more. There are plenty of things to think and worry about while playing each game.* Detailed statistics, unit and damage reports at the end of the match help you understand how you're playing* Two types of economy and battle mechanics mean that balancing elements of your battlefield is key, and changes from match to matchMistakesThe vast majority of Tower Wars' problems stem from crappy handling of multiplayer. At the time of review, multiplayer is all but dead unless you play Ranked matches, and many players simply don't care about the ladder.The landscape of multiplayer on the Ranked system is frankly a horrible mess. The nature of games means that your first few moves in a multiplayer game can determine whether you'll win or lose. In games like Starcraft, for example, you can make a decisive early move, but the seasoned enemy can overcome it with their skill. In Tower Wars this isn't the case, and you can sometimes tell you've lost a game after just a handful of moves.Couple that with the fact that there are people abusing the ranking system by intentionally losing matches and reducing their ranking, just to play against easier opponents, for whatever reason, and you, as a new player, will encounter basically 2 types of matches:* Your opponent is drastically better than you and will stomp you in the first few moves* Your opponent is drastically better than you but is intentionally losing their ranking score, so will let you kill them within the first few movesThis makes the game all but pointless in multiplayer for most, and is unlikely to change in the foreseeable future. The only realistic approach, for many, is finding friends or groups who still play this game, but due to the problems mentioned above, those are now very rare.As for single player, it has problems too:* There's no compelling reason to keep playing single-player other than the gameplay. If you don't enjoy playing games for their own sake, there's no new units, new abilities or interesting changes to keep you playing other than a different map and a harder difficulty.* The A.I. difficulty is extremely hard in the final single-player levels, and may be too much even for a committed playerRecommendationsPriced at just £5.59/7.99€/$7.99, Tower Wars clocks in at around 3-4 hours gameplay in the single-player campaign, and would be really good value for money if there were an active multiplayer. Unfortunately the public multiplayer is all but a waste of time unless you are a glutton for punishment, or you can find people to play with.* There are some fantastic multiplayer guides and tutorials from the community which may make uneven multiplayer worth suffering through for some* Tower Wars has Steam Workshop support, but is almost empty and can be ignored, but does offer a couple extra maps for those inclined

												This game wasn't the most terrible game I ever played. However, it has a lot of glaring flaws in how it was designed. First you aren't given enough money to begin with to really implement any real strategy. So it becomes a race between either making sure your enemy never gets a single minion through or sending as many through as possible and winning before your enemy does with minimal defenses. The defenses also are not well designed at all. They only work well all used together meaning there are points in a match that feel slow because of this. Not only that but the defenses just feel weak overall. As opposed to the mod this game was based on, The WC3 map Tower Wars. Everything in the game is in between either being too cheap or too expensive. Getting more income should always be devilishly expensive because it is basically their version of upgrading your tier like in most RTS. It is just too cheap in this game. Meanwhile some upgrades are either too cheap or too expensive. Which leads to totally unfair advantages during the mid point of the game. With no real way to win in a realistic amount of time for a long game. Honestly the game would be much better if they only balanced it better as most of the problems I have with it is just the balance. The game has too much depth in areas too. The game should be a little more simple. Like there is no need to upgrade specific troops in stats, if you can already upgrade all troops in the game in a seperate menu. Instead they should have maybe had 3 levels or so, and unlock abilities instead. The progression of tiering up your sends should be much longer too, so that weaker sends have a point to them. Towers and Sends should all be much stronger as well so it is actually fun playing the game. Towers need much more depth to them as well as having customizable tiers for defense only make sense if the sends can be. The Towers don't even feel like they are from the same game. These are all the problems the game has and the only real upside I can give it is that it is fun to play once in a while with friends. However, once you both learn the meta of the game it can get really boring.

Posted: March 29, 2014
												Summary: Misleading, poorly designed clickfestDetail:Taking a look at the cartoonish, over-the-top graphics, one gets the impression that this is a family friendly, childish (in a good way) game, great for relaxing and enjoying some simple cartoon destruction with a laid back style and maybe mild challenges.  Going through the not-very-detailed tutorial, the joking dialogue confirms your impression.  When the guidance is complete (having forced you forward so you couldn't really watch the effects of what you were told to do since the action was off the screen while the text pop-ups prevented you from scrolling), however, and you are told to defeat the AI that was allegedly designed to be laughably simple, you eerily discover that it is strangely not so easy.Brushing it off and moving on to the first opponent AI, the real game quickly shows itself.  Still not really sure when you are supposed to use which towers and units (i.e. what the strengths are meant to be), you are left to figure it out in real-time.  A bit of delay and boring start ensues, but the pace quickly picks up.  Expect to loose if you actually try to take the time to read the in-game descriptions for each unit and tower to learn as the AI rapidly ramps up its waves.  I am quite a tower game rookie, but since the game gives the impression that it would fit well for that situation, it is telling that I lost 3 or 4 times until beating the very first AI opponent (then beating the second on the first try since the design is so repetative before giving up on the third from the stupidity).  Most annoying is the fact that there is no time to really think about how to lay out your towers, the waves come too fast, you have to memorize the map and already know what to do.  The fact that single player was an after-thought is quite evident given that, pathetically, there is nothing even as simple as a game speed adjustment.  So while the AI happily processes away at the speed of electricity, its all on you to try to out-click it - the single biggest factor in destroying the potential enjoyability of the game - it is nothing but rushing to keep up.  If you step back and think about it, though, that really is the only way to make it "challenging", since the fixed, hex based maps are so pathetically constraining, there really is only one effective way to force the path through the "maze" at a high level, all you can do is select which towers to construct where.Which brings us to the next point.  How do you know which towers you really need?  Well it depens on what troops are being sent after you.  Do they have lots of shields? Armor? Health?  Can you watch and see how effective or ineffective your towers are?  NO!!, you can't!  When you click on a menu to bring up your options, the game forces your screen to look at a certain area.  For instance, if you bring up your castle, your screen MUST look at it, ditto your mines, etc., therefore you cannot browse through and think about upgrades while also watching the assault in the background.  If you try to go around upgrading, you will suddenly have an attacker at your castle door with ample shields and not a clue where you need to add tower strength to prevent it.  If you sit on your hands while watching the action so that you can see where your weaknesses are, you won't have time to actually implement the necessary changes.Then there is the fact that Every. Single. Time. you launch your troops, the "king" announcer randomly picks one of 2 or 3 lame and incredibly repetitive and annoying phrases to say when you are already frustrated at yet another "strategy" game that has almost no strategy (or even tactics), replacing it with yet another round of who can click the fastest.I could rant on, but I have wasted enough of my own life on both the game and this review already.  I have not had a Steam account very long, but this is the first game I have uninstalled without beating.  Quite surprising given the lousy 5 (simplistic) maps and 10 AI opponents you have to select between, yet another misleading indicator for this poorly designed game and its confused developers.

Arrange a match with friend before you jump into multiplayer. If you can find someone with same skill level, well, I guess it's fun.Learning curve is surprisingly not that hard. There's still a learning curve, but from what I can see, not as steep as Castle Fight. Also there's little teamwork required unlike in Castle Fight so yeah... You just need to send your units (controlled by AI after you launch them) into enemy's castle and simultaneously defend you castle by making maze (hello Sanctum 1). When engaging enemies, you earn points that you can use to hire workers to obtain more gold, upgrade your tech trees to obtain more units and make them stronger. Rinse and repeat - don't forget to keep creating maze.Typical tower defense stuffs, heh.All in all, a promising game but lacking execution and less polished. Despite the workshop implemented already, there's little to none content in it. Sad, but that's true. Maybe with longer developer supports and a few sales here and there the game can be improved and has bigger player base.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												This game has a serious User Interface problem. It struggles to communicate even the most basic things for the Tower Defence genre. For example: when you are going to place a tower, the menu that shows tower placement options actually gets in the way of the range indicator for the towers. Also, the tower placement menu is only visible for as long as you hold the mouse button down; and if you accidentaly misclick a tile, that counts as pressing the button (to show the menu) and releasing it (to select an action i.e. placing a tower), which means you'll built lots of towers by mistake. The buttons in the interface are way too small, there are no information tooltips for most of them (what the hell does the exclamation mark do exactly? It turns red when I click it, but that's it). The fonts are ugly and inconsitent. The creeps' HP bars are hard to read. The pathing of the creeps is smart, but it doesn't show you how it will change until you actually place your towers, so you have to think extra hard before you do anything. Even deleting units from your units queue is painfully hard, you have to double click each individual unit (also, this information is nowhere to be found, I figured it out by mistake). Seriously, the developers need to take a cold, hard look at their User Interface and User Experience. The game is frustrating before it even starts. These interface issues were enough to make my experience (with a friend, actually) a nightmare, to the point where I ragequitted a co-op game that I was winning. Aside from that, I'd say that the game actually tries to be funny (in the tutorial and in all the tips and vocal taunts), but really it is not. And bad comedy is worse than no comedy at all.The more I think about this game, the more I find things to hate about it. Having two different resources seems like a good idea in theory, but it sucks in game. There are loads of options everywhere and on everything, but most of them are not actually viable - they're useless clutter. You have 3 mines (where you get your resources from) and you can upgrade each one individually. Why? Why not have just one place to control your resource gathering? By the way, the "Tower Defence" aspect of this game is secondary. This is a resource-management game, pure and simple: it's about MIN/MAXING meaningless numbers on what could otherwise be an Excel sheet. Except there's a guy yelling at you trying to be a funny british king figure, and failing hard at it.This game is not worth it.

												I love this game. It's got all the classic elements of a good tower defence game, and the hex-based grid is awesome.Things I Like:[+] Tower defense mechanics.[+] Single Player gameplay is challenging and rewarding.[+] Hex based grid is just fantastic.[+] Gameplay is unique (as far as I'm aware anyway.)[+] The art such as tower models, and characters are very nice, as well as the maps, effects, all of it. It's very sleek. [+] Maps and the randomness created by the mines moving around each game is awesome.[+] The audio (including character voices) is amusing and well-done.[+] User Interface is generally well-designed, and amusing, and looks good.[+] The camera is perfect.Issues:[-] User Interface and I have our disagreements. I want it to go back to a menu or let me restart right after I lose angrily and it just sits there and I hit buttons to try to make it go away, until it lets me exit the current map.[-] When exiting a map that you just lost (or won), there is small text that must be clicked, and I haven't found a key on the keyboard to make it click through. I would like to be able to hit [ESC] or [ENTER] and have it go back to the menu at that point.[-] I often find myself accidentally clicking and then it defaults to building a tower where I had no intention of putting a tower, and then I am sad.[-] From what I've played it doesn't seem there's a lot of genuine strategy. You just have to balance upgrading mines, units, and global unit stats, and keep everything moving in the right direction and build a standard set of towers with as long a maze as possible. If you build some towers in large quantities, you'll lose, if you focus on one type of upgrades, you'll lose.[-] UI doesn't agree with my pen tablet entirely. when I click to upgrade a tower it clicks constantly, and sometimes does odd things, which isn't that surprising.[-] Hotkeys for things are not displayed. If I could hover over the send button and it would say something like "[SPACE] to Send Troops" or "[1] to queue this troop". Those keyboard shortcuts are useful but I only learned them through the tutorial or tips or guesswork. I like hovering over things for information.[-] Hovering over units does not give any info about what unit they are or their health. I assume that's how they planned it, but I would very much like more information at my fingertips.[-] I find it hard to build a complex maze in a hex-grid (but that said, I'd still take a hex grid any day.)Other notes:[~] Gameplay is exceedingly challenging, getting me stuck on one bot for quite some time in single-player, and I can only imagine it's even harder against real people, as I'm sure I'll find out soon. It's a very delicate balancing act. The fact that it is hard is not a bad thing though. It's just not for people who aren't up for a serious challenge, or those with lots of skill already in other tower defense games.[~] Each game can be quite long, but I enjoy long games so I don't consider this bad.[~] Full disclosure: I bought it during the summer sale, for a very low price. I do think it's worth the asking price though, for sure.Conclusion:I love this game, despite it's flaws. I love it's style, I love hexagon-based games, and I love it's mechanics. If you're looking for a fun, straightforward tower defense game, I highly recommend it. This game requires patience, and a willingness to learn.

												This game is different from other tower defense games since it lets you defend AND attack at the same time. That's about it's only advantage.This game is below average at best. It is lacking balance, polish, it is lacking interesting upgrades, lacking transparency in numbers and stats on towers. What is the exact damage of my towers? What is the exact bonus against so and so? The game tells you nothing about the details, which is a shame considering most people who play this genre are people who like number crunching and optimising, and this game won't let you do so.But mostly what kills it for me is the lack of a "goal". Lack of that sens of "am i doing good or bad? how good I am doing?". The single player missions seem pointless, as the game does not tell you how other people did, and gives you no score or achievement to aim for. I played the first level for an hour, survived everything and upgraded everything, yet i felt like i wasted an hour... What was the point? Againt you can't compare your performance and have no point of reference, so the whole thing is an exercice in futility no matter how well you do.It seems the developers want you to jump into multiplayer and go against other people. But I do not believe that the system  is robust enough for multiplayer, the upgrades, towers, stats, units, nothing seems optimised, balanced, or even transparent in what it does and that is really unatractive for someone looking for a competitive game.Since the game is not transparent in its stats, it forces you to read guides and spend time on the forums, instead of simply playing and thinking / figuring out things for yourself (which i find is the most enjoyable aspect of tower defense games : number crunching), since i can't number crunch here i'd rather uninstall this game than rely in the community to tell me what is good and what is not. Seriously what would be the point of adopting solutions designed by others? You'd just be a bot running the cookie cutter solutions of another, instead of figuring out things for yourself. Not my idea of fun.All in all this is a tower game with a single innovative feature, but seeing as it does neither single player nor multiplayer well, there is no reason to buy it unless it gets heavily patched. Also looking at the dozen people on my friend list who bought this game, i don't see anyone who played this title for more than 2 hours, which reinforces the idea that this game is not very fun and offers very little bang for the buck.Time to uninstall this and go back to Defense Grid.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												Tower Wars, what more is there to say? The game plays around the game mode made popular by War Craft III in which the player constructs towers in a maze to protect their base (or in this game's instance, their castle). Its a simple style of gameplay for a very casual game that can be both relaxing, or in more difficult settings absolutely intense. Unfortunately, Tower Wars fails to deliver on any of that excitement that made tower defence games so very popular in the years past.A few review note this game as being easy, others stating that it is hard. Overall, the game is easy--until you hit the absolute best in any given map in which case its a waiting game for the creeps to get strong enough to make it to your castle. Games lasting an hour or more of just waiting for your maxed out maze to finally be defeated while you sit hopeless...and bored. That is the survival mode in a nutshell--lifeless and easy. Aided with a rather terrible user interface and rather bad maps it feels uninspired and a chore to get into.There now is multiplayer too, which like one of the single player modes adds the the ability to spend gold to buy "creeps" to send to the oppossing player's maze. This verses style worked fantastic in days past--the perfect balance in deciding to spend money for either offencive play or defencive play. While Tower Wars continues on this great gameplay, some of the same reasons that make the single player so dry still exist in multiplayer making it one of those games which simply does not draw the player in.Sure, my ideas of tower defence games is carved from the various mods from the early days of their introduction as mods for various Blizzard games, but I gave Tower Wars a chance to work with the genre to create new and interesting gameplay and build on it. It adds hexagonal tiles, which could have resulted in amazing new ways to making new mazes, alas the maps do not even permit very complex mazes thanks to their size. I simply cannot recommend this game to anyone, especially at the asking price of $8. It quite simply falls short.

												I love this game. It's got all the classic elements of a good tower defence game, and the hex-based grid is awesome.Things I Like:[+] Tower defense mechanics.[+] Single Player gameplay is challenging and rewarding.[+] Hex based grid is just fantastic.[+] Gameplay is unique (as far as I'm aware anyway.)[+] The art such as tower models, and characters are very nice, as well as the maps, effects, all of it. It's very sleek. [+] Maps and the randomness created by the mines moving around each game is awesome.[+] The audio (including character voices) is amusing and well-done.[+] User Interface is generally well-designed, and amusing, and looks good.[+] The camera is perfect.Issues:[-] User Interface and I have our disagreements. I want it to go back to a menu or let me restart right after I lose angrily and it just sits there and I hit buttons to try to make it go away, until it lets me exit the current map.[-] When exiting a map that you just lost (or won), there is small text that must be clicked, and I haven't found a key on the keyboard to make it click through. I would like to be able to hit [ESC] or [ENTER] and have it go back to the menu at that point.[-] I often find myself accidentally clicking and then it defaults to building a tower where I had no intention of putting a tower, and then I am sad.[-] From what I've played it doesn't seem there's a lot of genuine strategy. You just have to balance upgrading mines, units, and global unit stats, and keep everything moving in the right direction and build a standard set of towers with as long a maze as possible. If you build some towers in large quantities, you'll lose, if you focus on one type of upgrades, you'll lose.[-] UI doesn't agree with my pen tablet entirely. when I click to upgrade a tower it clicks constantly, and sometimes does odd things, which isn't that surprising.[-] Hotkeys for things are not displayed. If I could hover over the send button and it would say something like "[SPACE] to Send Troops" or "[1] to queue this troop". Those keyboard shortcuts are useful but I only learned them through the tutorial or tips or guesswork. I like hovering over things for information.[-] Hovering over units does not give any info about what unit they are or their health. I assume that's how they planned it, but I would very much like more information at my fingertips.[-] I find it hard to build a complex maze in a hex-grid (but that said, I'd still take a hex grid any day.)Other notes:[~] Gameplay is exceedingly challenging, getting me stuck on one bot for quite some time in single-player, and I can only imagine it's even harder against real people, as I'm sure I'll find out soon. It's a very delicate balancing act. The fact that it is hard is not a bad thing though. It's just not for people who aren't up for a serious challenge, or those with lots of skill already in other tower defense games.[~] Each game can be quite long, but I enjoy long games so I don't consider this bad.[~] Full disclosure: I bought it during the summer sale, for a very low price. I do think it's worth the asking price though, for sure.Conclusion:I love this game, despite it's flaws. I love it's style, I love hexagon-based games, and I love it's mechanics. If you're looking for a fun, straightforward tower defense game, I highly recommend it. This game requires patience, and a willingness to learn.

												I got this game from the GMG (Green Man Gaming) Snack Pack 2 bundle. My brother recommended me it. At first, I wasn't convinced. Even though the bundle was 5 games for 50 cents, I could've gotten some more PAYDAY 2 DLC for my pennies. As it turns out, the bundle was well worth getting. Tower Wars has been the only game I have played in the bundle. (and you can even see my icon is a unit from Tower Wars, proof of how fun this is)Tower Wars is a classic Tower Defense type game mixed with offense. If you have played the game Toy Soldiers before, this game is like Toy Soldiers taken a step further.Now, more in depth about Tower Wars:ModesMeat vs. Metal (their classic offline, "Player vs. Bot" mode)        Objective: Destroy the enemy's castleClassic Tower Defense (also offline, and self explaintory)        Objective: Fend off as many waves as you canRanked Season Play (get paired with someone and play a match, tracked by leaderboards)        Objective: Destroy the enemy's castleUnranked Play (play in a public or private lobby, nothing is scored on leaderboards)        Objective: Destroy the enemy's castleCo-op (pretty much Tower Defense w/ a friend)        Objective: Fend off as many waves as you canTowersThere are multiple towers, each do something different, all of them gain an advantage over one type of HP (shield, armor, or health), and gain a somewhat disadvantage over the others (not as effective).UnitsThe units are pretty interesting, there are 6 tiers. First is the guy on the logo (Mr. Moopsy).Second you can choose from knights or speedy guys.Third tier includes a  unit that increases DPS and speed, another giving health to units within range when killed, and last a unit that gives your units shields/increases the amount of shields.Fourth tier you earn Stanley Cluckerbottom. He is a stong unit with lots of armor, health and shields.Fifth tier you unlock the best by far (in my opinion) unit. The (unofficial name) Trojan Horse. The horse can be filled with more units. when the horse is destroyed, the units disembark, then the horse explodes. This gives all 1-3 tier units a protective shell, giving them a chance to get to the castle. This unit is able to be upgraded the most in the game, allowing armor upgrades, more space upgrades, and also random unit upgrades.Sixth tier you unlock the guy on my icon; Malevolent. He has no shield, but high damage, max armor, and max health. Most of the time I can get him through or almost through the enemies defenses.UpgradesUpgrades are REALLY important.You can upgrade units, your barracks, or your castle.Unit upgrades: They advance/unlock your units.Mine upgrades are basic. All you can do is purchase more miners to increase income and upgrade your mine to purchase more.Barrack upgrades: These upgrades give all your units an upgrade, but cost lots.Castle upgrades are also basic. you can increase your armor and DPS (gatling guns fend off intruders). Like the mines, you can upgrade to a higher tier to increase the armor/DPSThe most basic of them all, tower upgrades: All you can do is upgrade them 3 times to increase the effectivity/range.Balancing (IMPORTANT)Gold: You earn it slowly. Purchase more miners to earn more per second. required to do anything in game besides upgrading your unit (NOT UNLOCKING, UPGRADING)Battle Points (BP): Required to purchase any form of upgrade besides tower upgrades. Earned by units over the "TO BATTLE" line.Cooldown: The timer before you can send another wave of troops.Barrack Queue: Amount of units you can send in a waveOVERALLIn a briefing, I would give this a 7/10.Good gameNot enough mapsNo easy modding/map support (tried to make a map myself, their tool crashed on me)

												Bro, get this game. It's only 7.99 on right now and I've got about 80 hours into it. Pretty  amazing considering I spent less than 10 dollars on it. This game is tower defense, but instead of a CPU sending the same sequence of units over and over, you defend against another person attacking you, and you must do the same! Lay down towers to maze your enemy anywhere but your castle and relentlessly send until you break their lines and take down their castle. You also have an economy, an individual unit tech tree, a general tech tree that applies to all units, and upgradeable towers of all different varieties. The learning curve is easy peasy but yet there is so much depth and subtly to the game. Super laid back but intense at the same time.
